skill.description: Generate descriptive commit messages by analyzing git diffs. Use when the user asks for help writing commit messages or reviewing staged changes.

skill.author: Joseph OBrien

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only markdown documentation. No executable code, network calls, file system access, or external commands. Contains commit message templates and best practices guidance only.

content.user_title: Generate commit messages from git diffs
content.value_statement: Writing clear commit messages takes time and consistency. This skill provides structured guidance, conventional commit formats, and templates to generate descriptive commit messages automatically based on staged changes.
actual_capabilities: Analyze git staged changes to understand what was modified
Generate commit messages following conventional commits format
Apply appropriate commit types (feat, fix, docs, refactor, etc.)
Include breaking changes notation when detected
Add issue references and footer tokens to commits
Review commit message quality against best practices
limitations: Does not execute git commands directly
Does not modify or commit changes to repositories
Does not integrate with GitHub, GitLab, or other remotes
Does not access git history beyond what user provides

use_cases.title: Write clear commit messages
use_cases.description: Generate consistent, descriptive commit messages following industry standards for personal projects.

use_cases.title: Maintain commit history
use_cases.description: Create standardized commit messages across team repositories for better changelog generation.

use_cases.title: Document changes properly
use_cases.description: Write professional commit messages that help contributors understand changes and automate releases.

prompt_templates.title: Basic commit help
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me write a commit message for my staged changes. Here is the git diff output:

prompt_templates.title: Conventional format
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a conventional commit message for these staged changes using feat, fix, or other appropriate types:

prompt_templates.title: Breaking changes
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a commit message that indicates a breaking change in the API for these staged changes:

prompt_templates.title: Multi-file commits
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a comprehensive commit message for these multiple related file changes, grouping them logically:

output_examples.input: Generate a commit message for these staged changes that add user login functionality
output: feat(auth): add user login with email and password

best_practices: Use imperative mood for descriptions (add, not added; fix, not fixed)
Keep the subject line under 50-72 characters
Explain WHY the change was made, not just WHAT changed
Reference related issues using Closes # or Fixes # tokens
anti_patterns: Using vague messages like update, fix stuff, or changes
Including implementation details in the summary line
Using past tense (fixed, added instead of fix, add)
Writing long paragraphs in the subject line without body separation

faq.question: What commit types are supported?
faq.answer: feat, fix, docs, style, refactor, test, chore, perf, build, ci, and revert. Each maps to specific semantic versioning impacts.

faq.question: What is the maximum length for commit messages?
faq.answer: Subject lines should be under 72 characters. Body paragraphs can be longer but stay concise.

faq.question: Does this integrate with Git hosting platforms?
faq.answer: No. This skill generates message text. You apply the message when running git commit manually.

faq.question: Is my repository data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill only processes git diff text you provide. No repository data is stored or transmitted.

faq.question: Why are my commit messages not working?
faq.answer: Ensure you provide the full git diff --staged output. The skill needs to see what actually changed to generate accurate messages.

faq.question: How is this different from commit templates?
faq.answer: This skill actively analyzes your changes and generates appropriate messages. Commit templates only provide formats you fill manually.
